div.p:
>> Joyce: Hi, this is Joyce
Farrell.

Let's talk about arithmetic
operator precedence.

When you have arithmetic
statements

in a computer program, there
are rules of precedence.

These are the rules
that dictate the order

in which arithmetic
operations are carried out.

When you have more
than one operation

in a statement, anything within
parentheses is evaluated first.
After expressions

within parentheses are
evaluated, multiplication

and division are evaluated
moving from left to right.
After all multiplication

and division have been
evaluated, addition

and subtraction are evaluated
moving from left to right.

Finally, if there is
an assignment operation

in the statement,
assignment executes last.
Let's look at an example.

Suppose you have a programming
statement answer equals 2 plus 3
times parentheses 5 minus 1.
Looking at the rules

of precedence, the first one is
do anything within parentheses.

In this case, 5 minus 1 is within
parentheses, so that evaluates

to 4, so the expression becomes
answer equals 2 plus 3 times 4.

When the expression inside
parentheses has been reduced

to a single value, you can
eliminate the parentheses,

so the expression becomes
answer equals 2 plus 3 times 4.

The next rule of precedence
is to do multiplication

and division moving
from left to right.

There's no division
in this statement,

so the first multiplication
statement multiplies 3 times 4,

so the expression becomes
answer equals 2 plus 12.

There's no more multiplication
or division, so you can look
at the third rule of precedence,

which says do any
addition or subtraction.

In this case, there's
some addition,

so 2 plus 12 is 14,
answer equals 14.

The last rule of
precedence says

use the assignment operator
to assign the value to 14,

and at this point, in memory, the
spot called answer gets a 14
stored in it.
Let's look at another example:

result equals 24
divided by 2 divided

by parentheses 2 times
parentheses 1 plus 2.

Notice that for every opening
parentheses there's always a
closing parentheses.

Looking at the rules of
precedence, number 1 says

do the operations
inside parentheses.
When there are multiple sets

of parentheses, you take the
inside parentheses first.

The inside parentheses, in
this case, contain 1 plus 2,

so the expression changes
to result is 24 divided

by 2 divided by 2 times 3,
because of 1 plus 2 is 3.

The rules of precedence still
say parentheses are operated
on next. So 2 times 3 is 6,

so result becomes 24
divided by 2 divided by 6.

Since there are no more
parentheses, you can look

at the next rule of precedence
that says do multiplication
or division from left to right.

So moving from left to
right, 24 divided by 2 is 12,

so the expression
becomes 12 divided by 6.

Then still doing multiplication
or division from left
to right, 12 divided by 6 is 2.
Looking at the next rule

of precedence we do any
addition or subtraction.

In this case, there is no
addition or subtraction.

That's okay, we just move to
the next rule of precedence.

The last one says
make the assignment,

so in memory, a spot called
result finally has the value 2
assigned to it.

Those are the rules
of precedence
in arithmetic expressions.
Thanks for watching.
